head.title: “Heights of Wisdom, Depth of Fools” [Miscellaneous Drawing, MS I]

figure.p: The emblematic drawing was perhaps inspired by a passage in Harry and Lucy Concluded (1825) by Maria Edgeworth: only "those who are themselves children, or . . . those who know children right well" will credit Harry and Lucy's "sudden falls from the heights of wisdom to the depths of folly". The protagonists have been engaged in well-regulated learning, Harry teaching Lucy the mechanics of air pumps, using a pump made of glass in order to exhibit its inner workings. "How did Harry and Lucy spend the remainder of this morning, two whole hours?" the narrator asks. They spoil the glass pump by setting it to work in a muddy puddle, and they soil their clothing so badly that they are forced to hide in a tree to avoid their mother's summons to greet unexpected visitors. To their consternation, their shame and bashfulness cost them an interesting account of a shipwreck told by the visitors. Harry and Lucy beg their mother to repeat the story, but she refuses lest they lose this motivation to overcome their follies of bashfulness and carelessness with their things (1:103, and see 103-14).

Assuming that the source is correctly identified, Ruskin can be seen translating a didactic narrative into an emblematic picture by dispensing with the narrative details and fixing on the simple pictorial contrast of "heights of wisdom" and "depths of folly". Ruskin's edition of Harry and Lucy Concluded was not illustrated (see Physical Descriptions of Some Books Used by Ruskin in Youth); however, emblems were familiar to him from illustrations in other children's books, such as Christmas Tales by Solomon Sobersides. Its frontispiece represents Wisdom and Folly competing to lead the steps of youth, as explained by an accompanying text:
See here the Youth, by Wisdom led,
The Paths of Life, securely tread;
The dang'rous Lures of Folly shun,
And Virtue's Course serenely run.
The emblems in the woodcut are unpacked in an essay that introduces the copy of the book in the Hockliffe Project: "A masterpiece of its kind", the engraving shows "Wisdom (looking rather like Britannia) giving a book to a young boy, while Folly (distinguished by her fool's hat) tries to distract him with a rattle. Behind them, we see the solid and magnificent temple built by Wisdom, and the ruined temple which must be the result of heeding the 'Lures of Folly'" (“Stories before 1850. 0220: Anon. [‘Solomon Sobersides’], Christmas Tales”).

These traditional emblems are adapted to a child's text by putting a youth in the place of the classical hero featured in compositions such as Hercules at the Crossroads (1748) by Pompeo Girolamo Batoni. His seated naked hero weighs the alternatives offered on the one hand by Venus and on the other by the armored figure of Minerva, who points to the Temple of Fame on a hill.

As the final item in MS I, Ruskin's emblem seems to complement the "frontispiece of his own "Harry and Lucy Concluded . . . vol I" at the beginning of the Red Book. The shape of the deep ravine is an inversion of the oddly triangular shape labled "a rainbow" in the frontispiece.
